elements.content: When reacted with undecane-1,11-dicarboxylic acid under solvo-hydrothermal conditions in the presence of Mn­(II) cations and 1,10-phenanthroline, uranyl ions give two-dimensional honeycomb networks which assemble to form a 3-fold Borromean entanglement. This structure is closely related to that of the helicates previously obtained with the shorter dodecanedioic acid. Replacement of 1,10-phenanthroline by 2,2′-bipyridine leads to the formation of a neutral one-dimensional heterometallic polymer.
elements.clean_text: When reacted with undecane-1,11-dicarboxylic acid under solvo-hydrothermal conditions in the presence of Mn(II) cations and 1,10-phenanthroline, uranyl ions give two-dimensional honeycomb networks which assemble to form a 3-fold Borromean entanglement. This structure is closely related to that of the helicates previously obtained with the shorter dodecanedioic acid. Replacement of 1,10-phenanthroline by 2,2'-bipyridine leads to the formation of a neutral one-dimensional heterometallic polymer.

elements.content: A three-fold two-dimensional Borromean array is formed from complexation of uranyl ions by undecane-1,11-dicarboxylate, which is at variance with the helicates generated with the smaller dodecanedicarboxylate, both geometries being however closely related. In both cases, the [M­(phen)3]2+ counterions (M = 3d-block cation) have a structure-directing role, and replacement of phen by bipy results in isolation of completely different neutral species.
elements.clean_text: A three-fold two-dimensional Borromean array is formed from complexation of uranyl ions by undecane-1,11-dicarboxylate, which is at variance with the helicates generated with the smaller dodecanedicarboxylate, both geometries being however closely related. In both cases, the [M(phen)3]2+ counterions (M = 3d-block cation) have a structure-directing role, and replacement of phen by bipy results in isolation of completely different neutral species.

elements.content: Among the poly­(carboxylic acid)­s which have been considered in the design of uranyl–organic coordination polymers or frameworks, the aliphatic α,ω-dicarboxylic acids HOOC–(CH2) n−2–COOH (denoted as H2Cn) provide a family of divergent ligands with a regularly increasing separation between the two functional groups. Those with long chains (n up to 12) have been much investigated, particularly by Cahill’s group. Notably, [UO2(C6)­(4,4′-bipy)] (4,4′-bipy = 4,4′-bipyridine) displays triple polycatenation of two-dimensional (2D) networks, and it is thus one of the rare examples of entanglement known in uranyl structural chemistry. In contrast to this work with bipyridine derivatives used as coligands, counterions or guest species, we recently turned to 3d-block metal ions associated with chelating N-donors to generate counterions inducing different topologies. In the cases of C92– and C122–, this approach has allowed synthesis of the first actinide-containing triple-stranded helicates, [M­(bipy)3]­[(UO2)2(C9)3] (M = Co, Ni; bipy = 2,2′-bipyridine) and [M­(phen)3]­[(UO2)2(C12)3] (M = Mn, Co; phen = 1,10-phenanthroline). While C92– appears to be the shortest member of the Cn 2– family allowing this geometry (C82– gives a heterometallic metallacycle under similar conditions), the question of the behavior of ligands with n > 12 deserves further examination. Using the same experimental conditions as in this former work, two uranyl complexes of undecane-1,11-dicarboxylate, C132–, could now be isolated in the presence of manganese­(II) cations and either bipy or phen, and they were characterized by their crystal structure. This ligand has the longest chain found so far in crystallographically characterized metal ion complexes of Cn 2–, no example with n > 12 being reported in the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD, Version 5.37).
elements.clean_text: Among the poly(carboxylic acid)s which have been considered in the design of uranyl-organic coordination polymers or frameworks, the aliphatic α,ω-dicarboxylic acids HOOC-(CH2) n-2-COOH (denoted as H2Cn) provide a family of divergent ligands with a regularly increasing separation between the two functional groups. Those with long chains (n up to 12) have been much investigated, particularly by Cahill's group. Notably, [UO2(C6)(4,4'-bipy)] (4,4'-bipy = 4,4'-bipyridine) displays triple polycatenation of two-dimensional (2D) networks, and it is thus one of the rare examples of entanglement known in uranyl structural chemistry. In contrast to this work with bipyridine derivatives used as coligands, counterions or guest species, we recently turned to 3d-block metal ions associated with chelating N-donors to generate counterions inducing different topologies. In the cases of C92- and C122-, this approach has allowed synthesis of the first actinide-containing triple-stranded helicates, [M(bipy)3][(UO2)2(C9)3] (M = Co, Ni; bipy = 2,2'-bipyridine) and [M(phen)3][(UO2)2(C12)3] (M = Mn, Co; phen = 1,10-phenanthroline). While C92- appears to be the shortest member of the Cn 2- family allowing this geometry (C82- gives a heterometallic metallacycle under similar conditions), the question of the behavior of ligands with n > 12 deserves further examination. Using the same experimental conditions as in this former work, two uranyl complexes of undecane-1,11-dicarboxylate, C132-, could now be isolated in the presence of manganese(II) cations and either bipy or phen, and they were characterized by their crystal structure. This ligand has the longest chain found so far in crystallographically characterized metal ion complexes of Cn 2-, no example with n > 12 being reported in the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD, Version 5.37).

elements.content: The complex [Mn­(phen)3]­[(UO2)2­(C13)3] (1), shown in , crystallizes in the same centrosymmetric space group and with similar unit cell parameters as the previously reported helicates [M­(phen)3]­[(UO2)2­(C12)3] (M = Mn, Co), so that the same triply linked dinuclear uranyl units could be expected. Surprisingly, the structure found is quite different, although the location of the uranyl cations and the counterions is the same. Each uranyl ion, on a 3-fold rotation axis, is chelated by three carboxylate groups, with an average U–O­(carboxylate) bond length of 2.45(2) Å, and the Mn2+ cation is at the intersection between a 3-fold rotation axis and three 2-fold ones orthogonal to it. Instead of connecting two uranyl ions adjacent to one another on the same 3-fold axis, the three ligands link each uranyl ion to three other ones, thus forming a very undulated 2D assembly perpendicular to the c axis with honeycomb (hcb) {63} topology. The hexagonal cells have a very marked chair conformation and a large size, with a distance of ca. 28.7 Å between opposite metal centers (Figure S1). Three such hcb networks are entangled to form a sheet through formation of Borromean links as shown in . As other 2D → 2D parallel entanglements involving such links, this system is of the Brunnian type (deletion of one network results in the complete separation of the two remaining). Complex 1 is apparently the first example of this somewhat uncommon topology to involve an actinide cation. The thickness of the sheets (which is the same as that spanned by each individual network) is ca. 13.6 Å between the centers of the outermost oxo atoms, or ca. 10.0 Å between uranium centers, the latter value being at the upper end of the range (3.0–9.6 Å) generally observed for honeycomb layer thickness in topologically analogous systems. This interuranium distance is slightly larger than that in the helicate species containing C122– (9.4–9.5 Å), and the distance between uranium atoms connected by C132– in 1 (16.8 Å) is also larger than its counterpart (between unconnected atoms) in the helicate species (16.5 Å). This enlargement of the interuranium distances in 1 reflects the increased length of the ligand, but the difference in connectivity between the two species, illustrated in , is primarily an effect of the very high flexibility of the aliphatic chain, which allows it to adopt either a curved shape in C122– or an elongated one in C132–, with probably little energy difference between them. In both cases, the central part of the aliphatic chain, which determines the connectivity, is in fact very badly resolved in the crystal structure (and disordered over two positions in the helicate), and it could only be refined with extensive use of restraints on bond lengths, bond angles, and displacement parameters (see Supporting Information). However, it is notable that the location of the electronic density in the difference Fourier maps clearly reveals the course followed by the chain in each species (although the presence of a small proportion of the alternative one cannot absolutely be ruled out).

Surprisingly, the structure found is quite different, although the location of the uranyl cations and the counterions is the same. Each uranyl ion, on a 3-fold rotation axis, is chelated by three carboxylate groups, with an average U-O(carboxylate) bond length of 2.45(2) Å, and the Mn2+ cation is at the intersection between a 3-fold rotation axis and three 2-fold ones orthogonal to it. Instead of connecting two uranyl ions adjacent to one another on the same 3-fold axis, the three ligands link each uranyl ion to three other ones, thus forming a very undulated 2D assembly perpendicular to the c axis with honeycomb (hcb) {63} topology. The hexagonal cells have a very marked chair conformation and a large size, with a distance of ca. 28.7 Å between opposite metal centers (Figure S1). Three such hcb networks are entangled to form a sheet through formation of Borromean links as shown in . As other 2D → 2D parallel entanglements involving such links, this system is of the Brunnian type (deletion of one network results in the complete separation of the two remaining). Complex 1 is apparently the first example of this somewhat uncommon topology to involve an actinide cation. The thickness of the sheets (which is the same as that spanned by each individual network) is ca. 13.6 Å between the centers of the outermost oxo atoms, or ca. 10.0 Å between uranium centers, the latter value being at the upper end of the range (3.0-9.6 Å) generally observed for honeycomb layer thickness in topologically analogous systems. This interuranium distance is slightly larger than that in the helicate species containing C122- (9.4-9.5 Å), and the distance between uranium atoms connected by C132- in 1 (16.8 Å) is also larger than its counterpart (between unconnected atoms) in the helicate species (16.5 Å). This enlargement of the interuranium distances in 1 reflects the increased length of the ligand, but the difference in connectivity between the two species, illustrated in , is primarily an effect of the very high flexibility of the aliphatic chain, which allows it to adopt either a curved shape in C122- or an elongated one in C132-, with probably little energy difference between them. In both cases, the central part of the aliphatic chain, which determines the connectivity, is in fact very badly resolved in the crystal structure (and disordered over two positions in the helicate), and it could only be refined with extensive use of restraints on bond lengths, bond angles, and displacement parameters (see Supporting Information). However, it is notable that the location of the electronic density in the difference Fourier maps clearly reveals the course followed by the chain in each species (although the presence of a small proportion of the alternative one cannot absolutely be ruled out).

elements.content: Top: View of complex 1. Displacement ellipsoids are drawn at the 20% probability level, and hydrogen atoms are omitted. Bottom: View of the packing down the c axis with uranium coordination polyhedra in yellow and those of manganese in green.
elements.clean_text: 1  Top: View of complex 1. Displacement ellipsoids are drawn at the 20% probability level, and hydrogen atoms are omitted. Bottom: View of the packing down the c axis with uranium coordination polyhedra in yellow and those of manganese in green.

elements.content: Nodal representation of the Borromean-type association of three networks in compound 1, viewed down an axis slightly inclined from c.
elements.clean_text: 2  Nodal representation of the Borromean-type association of three networks in compound 1, viewed down an axis slightly inclined from c.

elements.content: Comparison of the connectivities in the helicate built from C122– (top) and complex 1 (bottom), both viewed down the c axis. Uranium coordination polyhedra are yellow and those of manganese are green.
elements.clean_text: 3  Comparison of the connectivities in the helicate built from C122- (top) and complex 1 (bottom), both viewed down the c axis. Uranium coordination polyhedra are yellow and those of manganese are green.

elements.content: The main interactions between the anionic uranyl-containing sheets and the counterions are obviously mainly electrostatic. Among the less important ones, which may have an effect on the specific orientation of the counterion in the lattice, a possibly significant CH···π interaction (H···centroid 2.74 Å), as well as several CH­(cation)···O hydrogen bonds involving oxo or carboxylate acceptors (H···O 2.55–2.76 Å, C···O 3.01–3.68 Å) can be discerned. Overall, the counterion environment is not very different from that in the helicates.
elements.clean_text: The main interactions between the anionic uranyl-containing sheets and the counterions are obviously mainly electrostatic. Among the less important ones, which may have an effect on the specific orientation of the counterion in the lattice, a possibly significant CH⋅⋅⋅π interaction (H⋅⋅⋅centroid 2.74 Å), as well as several CH(cation)⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds involving oxo or carboxylate acceptors (H⋅⋅⋅O 2.55-2.76 Å, C⋅⋅⋅O 3.01-3.68 Å) can be discerned. Overall, the counterion environment is not very different from that in the helicates.

elements.content: With C92– and C122–, the nature of the N-donor ligand of the counterion has a clear effect on the geometry of the complex formed since helicates are only obtained with the couples C92–/bipy and C122–/phen, the reverse associations giving 2D assemblies (bearing no relation to the present one), while neither bipy nor phen appears to be suitable for helicate formation with C102–. As previously noted, this indicates that the counterion probably plays a structure-directing role in the synthesis of these helicates. In the present case, replacement of phen by bipy results in the formation of the complex [UO2Mn­(C13)2­(bipy)2] (2), represented in . Here also, the uranium atom is chelated by three carboxylate groups, with an average U–O­(carboxylate) bond length of 2.469(13) Å. Two ligands bridge two uranyl ions to form a centrosymmetric dinuclear metallacycle, while another one is bound to one uranyl cation at one end and to two manganese cations at the other, in a bridging bidentate fashion. Each manganese center is bound to two oxygen atoms and two chelating bipy molecules, the coordination environment being distorted octahedral. This connectivity gives rise to the formation of a one-dimensional polymer running along the [1 2 2̅] axis which displays an alternation of uranyl and manganese centrosymmetric dinuclear units. This complex is close to the [UO2M­(C8)2­(phen)2]2 (M = Mn, Co) molecular species previously described, the increased dimensionality being due to the manganese-bound carboxylate group being chelating in the latter species and bridging in 2.
elements.clean_text: With C92- and C122-, the nature of the N-donor ligand of the counterion has a clear effect on the geometry of the complex formed since helicates are only obtained with the couples C92-/bipy and C122-/phen, the reverse associations giving 2D assemblies (bearing no relation to the present one), while neither bipy nor phen appears to be suitable for helicate formation with C102-. As previously noted, this indicates that the counterion probably plays a structure-directing role in the synthesis of these helicates. In the present case, replacement of phen by bipy results in the formation of the complex [UO2Mn(C13)2(bipy)2] (2), represented in . Here also, the uranium atom is chelated by three carboxylate groups, with an average U-O(carboxylate) bond length of 2.469(13) Å. Two ligands bridge two uranyl ions to form a centrosymmetric dinuclear metallacycle, while another one is bound to one uranyl cation at one end and to two manganese cations at the other, in a bridging bidentate fashion. Each manganese center is bound to two oxygen atoms and two chelating bipy molecules, the coordination environment being distorted octahedral. This connectivity gives rise to the formation of a one-dimensional polymer running along the [1 2 2̅] axis which displays an alternation of uranyl and manganese centrosymmetric dinuclear units. This complex is close to the [UO2M(C8)2(phen)2]2 (M = Mn, Co) molecular species previously described, the increased dimensionality being due to the manganese-bound carboxylate group being chelating in the latter species and bridging in 2.

elements.content: Top: View of complex 2. Displacement ellipsoids are drawn at the 30% probability level, and hydrogen atoms are omitted. Bottom: The heterometallic 1D polymer.
elements.clean_text: 4  Top: View of complex 2. Displacement ellipsoids are drawn at the 30% probability level, and hydrogen atoms are omitted. Bottom: The heterometallic 1D polymer.

elements.content: The polymeric assembly in 2 being neutral, weak interactions are expected to be more effective in the packing (Figure S2) than in the ionic species 1. Indeed, one parallel-displaced π-stacking interaction is probably present [centroid···centroid distance 3.752(5) Å, slippage 1.59 Å], as well as CH···π interactions involving either aromatic or aliphatic hydrogen atoms (H···centroid distances 2.50 and 2.97 Å, respectively).
elements.clean_text: The polymeric assembly in 2 being neutral, weak interactions are expected to be more effective in the packing (Figure S2) than in the ionic species 1. Indeed, one parallel-displaced π-stacking interaction is probably present [centroid⋅⋅⋅centroid distance 3.752(5) Å, slippage 1.59 Å], as well as CH⋅⋅⋅π interactions involving either aromatic or aliphatic hydrogen atoms (H⋅⋅⋅centroid distances 2.50 and 2.97 Å, respectively).

elements.content: The present results thus show that, in the family of complexes [M­(phen)3]­[(UO2)2­(C12/13)3], increasing the aliphatic chain length by one unit results in a drastic change in connectivity, and thus in the dimensionality of the species formed, while retaining the same arrangement of uranyl cations, carboxylate groups, and counterions. The difference between the helicate (C122–) and the Borromean links (C132–) systems appears to be a consequence of the extreme flexibility of the long aliphatic chains, which allows them to adopt either curved or elongated conformations, respectively (with the frequent drawback of favoring also structural disorder, often to a problematic degree). In both cases, replacement of phen by bipy leads to utterly different structures, with, in the case of C132–, both uranyl and manganese being included in carboxylate-bridged neutral chains. This last observation is indicative of the subtle structure-directing effects exerted by the N-donor species in these systems.
elements.clean_text: The present results thus show that, in the family of complexes [M(phen)3][(UO2)2(C12/13)3], increasing the aliphatic chain length by one unit results in a drastic change in connectivity, and thus in the dimensionality of the species formed, while retaining the same arrangement of uranyl cations, carboxylate groups, and counterions. The difference between the helicate (C122-) and the Borromean links (C132-) systems appears to be a consequence of the extreme flexibility of the long aliphatic chains, which allows them to adopt either curved or elongated conformations, respectively (with the frequent drawback of favoring also structural disorder, often to a problematic degree). In both cases, replacement of phen by bipy leads to utterly different structures, with, in the case of C132-, both uranyl and manganese being included in carboxylate-bridged neutral chains. This last observation is indicative of the subtle structure-directing effects exerted by the N-donor species in these systems.

References

Synthesis of [Mn(phen)3]­[(UO2)2(C13)3] (1). Undecane-1,11-dicarboxylic acid (H2C13, 13 mg, 0.05 mmol), UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (17 mg, 0.03 mmol), Mn(NO3)2·4H2O (5 mg, 0.02 mmol), 1,10-phenanthroline (9 mg, 0.05 mmol), DMF (0.25 mL), and demineralized water (0.5 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 140 °C under autogenous pressure, yielding light pink crystals of complex 1 within 10 days. The solution was filtered while hot, and the crystals were washed with hot water (12 mg, 43% yield based on U). Anal. Calcd for C75H90MnN6O16U2: C, 48.37; H, 4.87; N, 4.51. Found: C, 48.10; H, 4.79; N, 4.47%. Synthesis of [UO2Mn(C13)2­(bipy)2] (2). Undecane-1,11-dicarboxylic acid (H2C13, 13 mg, 0.05 mmol), UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (17 mg, 0.03 mmol), Mn(NO3)2·4H2O (10 mg, 0.04 mmol), 2,2′-bipyridine (13 mg, 0.08 mmol), DMF (0.25 mL), and demineralized water (0.5 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 140 °C under autogenous pressure, yielding light yellow crystals of complex 2 within 10 days. The solution was filtered while hot, and the crystals were washed with hot water (11 mg, 39% yield based on H2C13). Elemental analysis results indicate possible hydration of the sample, with ca. 3 water molecules being present. Anal. Calcd for C46H60MnN4O10U + 3H2O: C, 46.98; H, 5.66; N, 4.76. Found: C, 46.66; H, 5.16; N, 4.61%.

elements.content: Crystal data for 1: C75H90MnN6O16U2, M = 1862.52, trigonal, space group P3̅1c, a = 13.4563(2), c = 23.2643(4) Å, V = 3648.14(14) Å3, Z = 2. Refinement of 152 parameters on 2329 independent reflections out of 144617 measured reflections (R int = 0.012) led to R 1 = 0.058, wR 2 = 0.163, S = 1.181, Δρmin = – 1.76, Δρmax = 1.85 e·Å–3. Crystal data for 2: C46H60MnN4O10U, M = 1121.95, triclinic, space group P1̅, a = 13.3568(9), b = 14.7360(6), c = 15.3668(9) Å, α = 115.992(3), β = 94.942(3), γ = 113.730(3)°, V = 2358.8(3) Å3, Z = 2. Refinement of 623 parameters on 8944 independent reflections out of 118644 measured reflections (R int = 0.055) led to R 1 = 0.053, wR 2 = 0.151, S = 1.104, Δρmin = – 1.65, Δρmax = 2.20 e·Å–3.

The solution was filtered while hot, and the crystals were washed with hot water (12 mg, 43% yield based on U). Anal. Calcd for C75H90MnN6O16U2: C, 48.37; H, 4.87; N, 4.51. Found: C, 48.10; H, 4.79; N, 4.47%. Synthesis of [UO2Mn(C13)2(bipy)2] (2). Undecane-1,11-dicarboxylic acid (H2C13, 13 mg, 0.05 mmol), UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O (17 mg, 0.03 mmol), Mn(NO3)2⋅4H2O (10 mg, 0.04 mmol), 2,2'-bipyridine (13 mg, 0.08 mmol), DMF (0.25 mL), and demineralized water (0.5 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 140 °C under autogenous pressure, yielding light yellow crystals of complex 2 within 10 days. The solution was filtered while hot, and the crystals were washed with hot water (11 mg, 39% yield based on H2C13). Elemental analysis results indicate possible hydration of the sample, with ca. 3 water molecules being present. Anal. Calcd for C46H60MnN4O10U + 3H2O: C, 46.98; H, 5.66; N, 4.76. Found: C, 46.66; H, 5.16; N, 4.61%.

metadata.title:
From Helicates to Borromean Links: Chain Length Effect
in Uranyl Ion Complexes of Aliphatic α,ω-Dicarboxylates
